greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest m such that n!-m and n!+m are both primes.
comment: For n=3,5,10,21,171,190,348, n! is an interprime, the average of two consecutive primes, see A053709. In general n! may be average of several pairs of primes, in which case the minimal distance is in the sequence. See also n^n and n!! as average of two primes in A075468 and A075410.
According to Goldbach's conjecture, a(n) always exists with a(n) = A047160(n!). - _Jens Kruse Andersen_, Jul 30 2014
link: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..100
example: a(4)=5 because 4!=24 and 19 and 25 are primes with smallest distance 5 from 4!.
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my (m=0); until (ok, ok = isprime(n!-m) && isprime(n!+m); if (!ok, m++);); return (m);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Apr 19 2013
results.author: _Zak Seidov_, Sep 18 2002
